Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High Temperature Corrosion Protection of Copper by the Application of an Aluminum Based Diffusion Coating
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will evaluate a low cost ceramic coating process to protect copper and its alloys from high temperature corrosion. The excellent thermal conductivity, workability, and relative chemical inertness of copper and its alloys make them attractive candidates for heat exchangers and electrical heating elements in water heating appliances. Unfortunately, high-temperature oxidation and condensate corrosion of copper heat exchangers limits their service life. To continue the use of copper in these applications, chemically inert, high temperature coatings with good thermal conductivity are required. The objective of this project is to achieve a range of ceramic and cermet coatings with varying thermal conductivity behavior through tailoring the composition and process variables of the coating.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is development of a disruptive, low cost ceramic coating process with wide-ranging applicability. The technology is amenable to a consumer appliance and automotive markets where corrosion protection is critical. These include home appliances, transportation radiators and heater cores, as well high temperature industrial brass and copper heat exchangers. If successful there are some important societal impacts?the more efficient water heater designs should lead to reduced materials consumption and greater diffusion of the high efficiency heater models into the market. For automotive applications, improved energy efficiency should result in reduced energy costs and reduced pollutants from lower exhaust emissions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NexTech Materials has developed a high performance, scalable aluminization process to prevent high temperature corrosion of metals. NexTech's coating has been extended from sheet and tubestock to woven and expanded metal meshes by tailoring the coating particle size, viscosity, and composition. Dip coating, aerosol spray and roll coating have all been used to cost-effectively coat these complex shapes.

In addition to materials design and refinement, key manufacturing parameters for the coating process were characterized - these include understanding the number of dip-coating/drying cycles required to achieve the required coating thickness and the deposited coating weight (both per pass and total). In addition, approaches to remove excess suspension (via draining or using a compressed air gun to blow off excess) were evaluated.

Discussions with potential customers and end-users identified several potential market opportunities for applying NexTech's coating technology to foam and mesh components. A promising application, with strong customer pull for gas burner manufacturers, is as a substitute for the more expensive woven superalloy meshes currently used as flame distributors in low NOx burners.

NexTech worked closely with potential customers to identify and demonstrate key product technical specifications, including oxidation resistance and thermal cycleability. Furthermore, annealing studies identified conditions to ensure a mechanically deformable coated component that can be pressed into its final shape. A parallel manufacturing analysis and cost modeling based on a detailed process flow model established a manufacturing roadmap to achieve the required cost-targets at high-volume production.

Three iterations of coated burner meshes have been provided to gas-burner manufacturers for collaborative testing. Initial results are very encouraging, as the coated mesh exhibits performance equivalent to its incumbent screens.
